ex_3_english: Well, leave the children there alone.
ex_4: A, pagkaláut sang ákon kapaláran!
ex_4_english: Oh, how unfortunate I am!
ex_5: A, indì ka magsapák sinâ.

def_1: A suffix of verbs that have a passive in - on.
compare: búhat, buháton, higúgma, higugmaón, táhud, tahúron, tahúdon, túman, tumánon, umá, úmhon, ísip, isípon, pa, tíndog, tindogón
notes:
This suffix occurs in the following tenses:
1.) The passive impersonal imperative.
Buháta iní. Do this. (búhat, buháton).
Higugmaá kag tahúra (—úda) ang ímo
ginikánan. Love and respect your parents,
(higúgma, higugmaón; táhud, tahúron,
tahúdon).
2.) The passive negative past. Walâ níya
pagbuháta iní. He did not do this. Walâ ni
la pagtumána ang íla katungdánan. They
have not ful?lled their duties, (túman,
tumánon).
3.) The passive negative present. Sa karón
walâ na níya pagaúmha iníng bánglid. He
now no longer tills this slope, (umá,
úmhon).
Tungúd sang kadamuón sang íla
mga páhò, walâ na níla pagaisípa, kóndì
ginasokób na lang sa pasungán. Owing to
the great quantity of their mangoes they no
longer count them, but measure them by
the bushel. (ísip, isípon).
Ngáa man nga
walâ mo pagapatindogá ang halígi? Why
are you not setting up the post? (pa,
tíndog, tindogón).

ex_2: A-a, ano na man iní! Maanó na lang akó!

ex_3_english: Do not let the dog snap at the meat.

ex_2_english: He has broad shoulders.

def_1: One with strong or broad shoulders
def_2: Broad-shouldered

ex_2: Nagaabák-abák gid karón ang íla mga kalisúd.

def_1: A small fish of a reddish colour.
To finish, take away or off (a loom or the like)
ex_1: Abána ang ákon háblon sa madalî nga saráng mahímò.
ex_1_english: Get my cloth off the loom as soon as possible.
ex_2: Ginában sang subâ ang ámon dútà.
ex_2_english: The river has washed away our land.
ex_3: Abánon mo na ang íya nga balayoón, kay nagtú-gon siá nga, kon maában na, ipadalá sa íya sa waláy lídan.
ex_3_english: Finish the cloth for making dresses, for she ordered it to be sent to her at once, when it was ready.
ex_4: Abáni akó sing duhá ka patádyong.
ex_4_english: Get me off the loom two native skirts, i.e. cloth sufficient for two such skirts called patádyong.
ex_5: Dílì makaában ang subâ siníng umá, kay may pángpang nga dínglì.

ex_6: Naában na ang tátlo ka búlan sa napúlò nga inogbulúthù níya sa koléhyo.
ex_6_english: Three months have gone by already of the ten he has to study at college.
ex_7: Ginában níya ang dakû níya nga mánggad sa mga kalingáwlingáwan kag waláy pulús nga mga kahinguyángan.
ex_7_english: He spent his great wealth on diversions and useless extravagance.
compare: hingápus, hingapús, kúhà, búhin, áb-ab, etc.

def_1: To take within range or sweep (of fire, etc.).
ex_1: Sang pagkasúnug sang baláy ni Fuláno naábang man ang ámon baláy.
ex_1_english: When N.N.’s house burned down, our house also was involved.
ex_2: Kon may súnug nga malapít sa plása, may katalágman nga abángon man sang kaláyo ang simbáhan.
ex_2_english: If a fire breaks out near the public square, there is danger that the church may also come within its destructive range.

def_2: To be greedy or desirous of getting a larger share than others.
ex_1_english: Don’t be greedy.

def_1: A tree well known for its beautiful leaves and large pods. These latter contain a great number of winged seeds that look like butterflies
To help, assist, aid, succour, lend a helping hand.
ex_1_english: Help him. Render him assistance. Lend him your aid.

def_2: To fan
ex_1_english: Fan me mother, for it is sultry.
ex_2: Kuyabí akó sang ímo abaníko.
ex_2_english: Fan me with your fan.
ex_3: Paabanikóhi ang mga bisíta, kay mabóhot kaáyo.
ex_3_english: Provide the visitors with fans, for it is very close.

def_1: A cigar, especially one made by machinery, and sold by tobacconists
ex_1: Bákli akó sing duhá ka abáno nga taglimá ka sentimós.
ex_1_english: Buy me two cigars of five centavos each.
ex_2: Indì akó makaúyon sang abáno kay matáb-ang; ginapasolabí ko gid ang piokós, kay labíng maísug.
ex_2_english: I do not like cigars sold by tobacconists, for they are too mild; I much prefer home-made cigars, because they are very strong.
notes: In contradistinction to the piokós—a home-made cigar, rolled by hand for private use

def_1: An expression of joy, surprise, astonishment, admiration, sorrow, grief and pain.
def_2: Oh! Ah! Alas! Hurrah!
ex_1: Abáo, katahúm siní nga daw lángit!
ex_1_english: Ah, how beautiful! How like heaven!
ex_2: Abáo nga pagkamakaloló-oy sang ákon karón nga kahimtángan!
ex_2_english: Oh the wretchedness of my present condition!
ex_3: May dakû nga súnug kahápon sa Iloilo kag madámù nga mga baláy nga dalágkù ang nagabó.— Abáo!
ex_3_english: There was a great ?re yesterday in Iloilo and many large buildings were burned to ashes.—Oh, really! Ah, this is terrible news!

def_1: To follow, go after (frequently with the meaning implied of summoning or calling back).
ex_1_english: Follow him (and tell him to come back). Summon him.
ex_2: Ipaábat ko siá sa kay Hosé.
ex_2_english: I shall send Joseph after him.
ex_3: Iábat mo ang bátà sa íya ilóy.
ex_3_english: Take the child after its mother.
ex_4: Paabáti si Andres sa kay Pédro or ipaábat si Andres sa kay Pédro.
ex_4_english: Order Peter to go after or call Andrew.
ex_5: Nagpaábat siá sa ákon sing kabáyo.
ex_5_english: He sent a horse after me.

def_2: Also: to follow up, follow from place to place.
ex_1: Ginabátábat sang mga polís ang makáwat túbtub nga íla madakúp (nadakúp).
ex_1_english: The police followed the thief from place to place till they caught him.
ex_2: Abát-abáton nínyo ang duhá ka pamatán-on nga nagtabanáy túbtub nga ínyo makítà kag ibálik nínyo dirí silá nga duhá.
ex_2_english: Follow the two young people that have eloped till you find them and bring the two of them back here.

def_1: To follow closely without going beyond, be barely sufficient
def_2: Just enough without anything to spare, living from hand to mouth.
ex_1: Ginaabátabát gid lang ang ámon pagkáon.
ex_1_english: We just manage to live from hand to mouth. The food we can procure is hardly enough to keep us alive.
ex_2: Ang ámon kinitáan abátabát gid lang sa ámon pangabúhì.
ex_2_english: Our earnings are barely enough for our living.

def_1: To join, enter, associate with, take to, mingle.
ex_1: Nagabáy na siá sa pagkapánday, pagkamangangawáy, etc.
ex_1_english: He has now taken to carpentry, has cast in his lot with the soldiery, etc.
ex_2: Dî mo pagiabáy ang ngálan sang Diós sa mga sugilánon nga kalibutánon.
ex_2_english: Do not mingle the name of God in worldly conversation.
ex_3: Indì mo pagábyan ang mga dîmatárung.
ex_3_english: Do not join with, associate with, wicked men. Abyí siá. Join him. Become his companion or associate.
ex_4: Ipaabáy mo ang ímo nga anák sa mga kaupdánan nga maáyo sing pamatásan.
ex_4_english: See that your child associates with companions of good behaviour.

def_2: Also: to meddle, put one’s nose in, interfere.
ex_1: Indì ka magabáyabáy sinâ nga mga butáng.
ex_1_english: Don’t meddle in those things. Don’t put your nose in such matters.

def_1: Liable to fall under a spell by which a benefit is changed into its opposite evil.
ex_1: Indì mo pagsingganán ang bátà nga matámbok siá, kay básì abáyan.
ex_1_english: Don’t tell the child that it is fat, because it might fall under an evil spell (and become lean or sick).
notes: This is a superstition. It is likely that after “abáyan” “sang áswang” is understood.

def_2: Light brown, of the colour of a hazel-nut.

def_1: To put on the back, etc.
For instance, for example; to imagine, think, say.
ex_1_english: Let us imagine, for example, that—.
ex_2: Kon magmasakít ikáw, ábi, ánhon mo?
ex_2_english: If you should get sick, say, what would you do?
ex_3: Anó, ábi, ang mahanabû kon—?
ex_3_english: What do you think will happen, if—?
notes: Also used ironically and sarcastically, especially in the phrase: Abi mo? Do you really think so? implying that he who thinks so is quite wrong, very imprudent, foolish, and the like.

def_2: To greet, salute, shake hands with
ex_1: Ginapadalá ko sa ínyo ang ákon abí-ábi.
ex_1_english: I send you my regards.
ex_2: Sa íla nga tanán ang ákon pagabí-ábi kag pagtáhud.
ex_2_english: To all of them I tender my greetings and respect.
ex_3: Abí-abíha siá.
ex_3_english: Salute him. Shake hands with him. Treat him well or hospitably.

def_2: To be friends
ex_1: Siá maáyo ko gid nga ábian.
ex_1_english: He is my best friend.
ex_2: Nagaábian silá.
ex_2_english: They are friends.
ex_3: Magabiánay kamó.
ex_3_english: Be friends.

def_1: To provide for a journey, get things ready

ex_1_english: Provide him with provisions. Invite him.
ex_2: Sín-o ang nagabiár sa ímo?
ex_2_english: Who invited you?

def_1: To urge, stimulate, animate, enliven, quicken, rouse.
ex_1_english: Urge him to greater exertions. Rouse or stimulate him.
ex_2: Abibahí ang íla trabáho.
ex_2_english: Put some liveliness—, animation—, energy—, into their work.

def_1: Open, accessible, affording free entrance or passage.
ex_1_english: The window is open, the passage is free, etc.

def_1: Capable, especially with regard to procreation. Mostly applied to domestic animals.

def_2: Rather capable.

def_1: Often also used in connection with men of loose morals
def_2: Lecher, fornicator, whoremonger
To cover the shoulders

def_1: Ability, capacity, expertness, talent, mastery, knowledge, dexterity.
ex_1: Walà siá sing abilidád sa amó nga palangakóan.
ex_1_english: He has no capacity for such an office

def_1: To move to and fro, to swing, to rock.
Let us see. Let us have a try.
ex_1: Hóo, abír, kon makabúhat ka sinâ.
ex_1_english: Yes, let us see, whether you can do that.
compare: tan-awón ta, ipakítà mo, tilawán ta, etc.

def_1: To advise, send notice, notify, inform.
ex_1_english: Did you inform him?
ex_2: Magsálig ka sa ákon, magaabisár gid akó sa íya.
ex_2_english: Trust me, I will certainly notify him.
notes: Abisár seems to be in use only in the active voice; for the passive abíso is commonly used.

def_2: To give notice, to send word, to notify, to inform.
ex_1_english: Notice! Attention!
ex_2: Abisóhi siá sang kamatáyon ni Fuláno.
ex_2_english: Inform him that N.N. is dead.
ex_3: Paabisóhan mo siá sang pagabút dirí sang íya amáy or ipaabíso mo sa íya nga nagabút dirí ang íya amáy.
ex_3_english: Send him word (through somebody else) of the arrival here of his father or that his father has arrived here.
compare: balítà, pahibaló, pasáyod, paálam, paáman, paándam, pamáan, etc.

def_1: Width, breadth, to widen, broaden, to make wide or wider.
ex_1: Sádto ánay makitíd ang dálan, karón nagáblang na.
ex_1_english: Formerly the road was narrow, now it has widened.
ex_2: Gináblang níla ang plása.
ex_2_english: They widened the public square.
ex_3: Ginpaáblang níla ang plása.
ex_3_english: They have had the public square widened.
ex_4: Sogóa ang pánday nga ablangón níya ang lamísa.
ex_4_english: Order the carpenter to make the table wider.
ex_5: Naablangán akó siníng takúd.
ex_5_english: This shutter (door, etc.) is too broad for me, or appears to me to be very broad or too broad.

def_2: Sociability
def_3: To be or become affable, friendly, sociable
ex_1_english: He has become affable or sociable now.
ex_2: Naablawán akó sa íya.
ex_2_english: He seems to me to be very friendly.
ex_3: Ipakilála ko sa ímo si Fuláno, kay sa waláy duhádúha pagaablawán ka gid sa íya.
ex_3_english: I will introduce N.N. to you, for without doubt you will find him very sociable, agreeable, affable.
compare: búgno, mabinugnóhon; kaáblaw, kaabláwan, mainabláwon, etc.

def_1: Shawl, covering for the shoulders and back
def_2: To use or wear a shawl.
ex_1_english: Look at that woman wearing a shawl.
ex_2: Pagaablayón ko gid iníng bunáng.
ex_2_english: I will certainly work this yarn up into a shawl.
ex_3: Iabláy lang iníng hábul, kay mátugnaw.
ex_3_english: Just use this blanket as a shawl, for it is cold.
ex_4: Ablayí ang bátà, agúd indì mapásmo sa matúgnaw nga hángin.
ex_4_english: Put a shawl around the child, lest it should catch a cold in the chilly air.
ex_5: Paablayí silá.
ex_5_english: Provide them with shawls. Put some shawls at their disposal,

def_1: To lean—, put one’s arm or hand—, on another’s shoulder.
An exclamation denoting aversion, horror, contempt, emphatic denial or negation.
def_2: Fie! Pshaw! Whew! Pooh!
ex_1_english: Pshaw, that’s a lie!
ex_2: Abô, índî akó magpáti sinâ.
ex_2_english: Fie I don’t believe that.
ex_3: Abô, pagkamalulúod siníng idô nga patáy kag inúdlan!
ex_3_english: Pooh what a horrible stench is coming from this dead and wormy dog.

ex_2_english: The fire burned our house to ashes.
ex_3: Abohán mo ang pínggan kag báso, agúd makúhà ang kadánlug.
ex_3_english: Clean the plate and glass with ashes, so that the greasy dirt may be removed.
ex_4: Ang abó nga ginpát-in sa áton mga ágtang sa ádlaw nga Miérkoles de Senísa (Ceniza) amó ang abó sang mga pálua (ráamos) nga nabenditáhan sang ádlaw nga Domingo de Rámos.
ex_4_english: The ashes with which our foreheads are marked on Ash-Wednesday are the ashes of the palms blessed on Palm-Sunday.
ex_5: Dílì mo pag-ipaabó sa íya iníng mga tulún-an, kay bisán dumáan na may kapuslánan pa.
ex_5_english: Don’t let him burn these books, for, though they are old, they are still of use.

def_1: A kind of small fish, growing to about six inches in length, and supposed to be very lazy and sleepy
def_2: Hence its name is often used to describe lazy and sleepy folks that are slow at their work, etc.
ex_1_english: He is like an àábo i.e. he is very lazy.
ex_2: Kaábo sa ímo!
ex_2_english: How lazy you are!
ex_3: Dáw ábo ka gid.
ex_3_english: You are just like an ábo.
ex_4: Ábo gid ang gwâ ta.
ex_4_english: The result of our undertaking is, was, or will be a complete failure.

def_2: A small ábo or any other fish somewhat resembling an ábo
Of an ash colour, ash-coloured, grey, ashy pale.
ex_1: Ang buút ko kaúnon ang páho nga abó-ábo na.
ex_1_english: I like to eat mangoes that are ash-coloured i.e. nearly ripe
ex_2: Ang íya kálò kag sapátos abó-ábo.
ex_2_english: His hat and boots are grey.

def_2: Kitchen

ex_1: Abáw, abohón gid ang ólo mo.
ex_1_english: Oh, your head is covered with—, full of—, ashes.

def_1: On the windward side, not under the lee, open or exposed to the wind

ex_1_english: My room is open to the north wind.

def_2: To be or get angry, exasperated, excited.
ex_1: May abóngho or nagaabóngho si Fuláno.
ex_1_english: N. N. is angry.

def_2: To manure.
ex_1_english: Manure the field.
ex_2: Ipaabóno ko sa ímo ang ákon umá, kon makasugtánay kitá sa nahanungúd sang isóhol ko sa ímo.
ex_2_english: I’ll let you manure my field, if we can come to an agreement as to how much I have to pay you in wages,

ex_2_english: That lawsuit worries me.
ex_3: Nagpaaborído siá sa ákon.
ex_3_english: He vexed or worried me.

ex_3: Ang makáwat walâ makaábri sang káha.

ex_4: Kon walâ ka sing yábi nga ikaábri sa ganháan, bingkalá na lang.
ex_4_english: If you have no key that can unlock the door, simply burst the door in.

def_1: Stimulant, appetizer, hors d’oeuvre, anything taken before a meal to whet the appetite.

ex_2: Ang mga babáye, nagapangabrígo.
ex_2_english: Women wear shawls.

ex_1: A, kon amó inâ, índì akó makaabsolbér sa ímo.

ex_2: Absolbehí siá.
ex_2_english: Absolve him. Give him absolution.

ex_1_english: He was acquitted by the judge.

compare: pagkabúang, puriákot, waláy sáyod; binúang, linóko, tinónto

def_1: Dexterity, adroitness, skill, quickness, expertness in invention or execution
def_2: To be or become expert, adroit, dexterous, skillful.

ex_1_english: Even a slow man, if he practises diligently, will become dexterous.
ex_2: Abtiká ang pagsulát.
ex_2_english: Try to write quickly.
ex_3: Naabtikán gid akó sang iya nga pagtahì.
ex_3_english: I was much impressed by her skill at sewing.

def_2: To hem, or edge garments by doubling and sewing.
ex_1: Abdi ang kamiséta ko or butangán mo singa abúd ang ákon kamiséta.
ex_1_english: Hem my shirt.

compare: pakinháson, búskay, mángay, sigáy, búli, lampírong, tipáy, búdyong

def_1: To ruffle, rumple, disturb the surface of
def_2: To rummage.

def_1: Abundant, plentiful, amply sufficient, more than enough, enough and to spare, abounding
def_2: To abound, be abundant, etc.
ex_1: Abúnda na or nagaabúnda na ang humáy.
ex_1_english: There is plenty of rice now.
ex_2: Naabundahán na kitá sang áton pangabúhì.
ex_2_english: We have now plenty to live upon.
ex_3: Maíwat karón ang ísdà, ápang magaabúnda man liwán kunína.
ex_3_english: Fish is now scarce, but it will be plentiful again.

def_1: To intercept, stop, catch (by crossing one’s way, or the like).
ex_1: Pinaabúngan (Pinaabungán) silá níya sa mga táo.
ex_1_english: He had them caught by his men. He ordered his men to catch them.

def_2: To misuse, abuse.
ex_1: Nagabusár siá sang kaálwan sang íya tíà.
ex_1_english: She abused the generosity of her aunt.
ex_2: Ayáw pagabusahí ang íya kaáyo.
ex_2_english: For God’s sake, don’t abuse her goodness.
ex_3: Ginabusahán níla ang íya kalólot.
ex_3_english: They took advantage of his kindness.

def_1: Abuse, wrong-doing, impropriety, reprehensible conduct, bad custom
def_2: To abuse, beguile, cheat, misuse.
ex_1_english: Oh, that is a bad custom. Ah, that is very improper.
ex_2: Dílì mo pagabusóhan ang ímo isigkatáo.
ex_2_english: Don’t cheat your fellow-man.

def_1: To arrive, come to, reach, to appear on the scene.
ex_1_english: When did you arrive?
ex_2: Sán-o ikáw magaabút?
ex_2_english: When will you come?
ex_3: Abutan ko ikáw karón sa ímo balay.
ex_3_english: I will come to see you presently at your home.
ex_4: Inabután siá sing dakû nga kahádluk.
ex_4_english: Great fear came over him.
ex_5: Anó ang ginapaabút mo?
ex_5_english: What are you waiting for?
ex_6: Paabutón ta pa ang koríyo kag ugáling magpaúlì.
ex_6_english: Let us wait for the mail to come in and then go home.
ex_7: Maglakát ka na sing madásig, agúd makaabút pa ikáw dídto sa napát-ud nga táknà.
ex_7_english: Now, walk quickly, that you may reach there at the appointed hour.

def_1: To reach, come up with, overtake, catch up with.
ex_1_english: I shall soon overtake you.
ex_2: Dalágan ka, agúd dílì ka maábut kag sungáyon sang karabáw nga simarón.
ex_2_english: Run, lest the wild buffalo should catch and toss you.
ex_3: Básì maábut mo pa siá sa dálan.
ex_3_english: Possibly you may overtake him yet on the road.
ex_4: Nagabút gid siá, ápang walâ makaábut sang misa.
ex_4_english: He arrived, indeed, but too late for hearing Mass. (Literally: “———, but he could not reach Mass”).

def_2: Also: Following one another in quick succession
To come and go, pass off and on
def_3: To come within reach, to reach nearly, but not quite.
ex_1_english: The disease attacks him periodically or in frequent fits.
ex_2: Ang kánding ginaabút-ábut na sang idô nga nagalagás.
ex_2_english: The goat is being nearly caught up to by the pursuing dog.
ex_3: Ang tá-ub nagaabút-ábut dirí siníng baybáyon túbtub sa tungâtúngà sinâ nga búgsok.
ex_3_english: The high tide on this beach usually rises to about the middle of that post.

def_1: To make or scramble for, gather, collect, lay up.
To receive in trust, to acquire with the prospect of ultimate ownership, to have some property provisionally settled on oneself during the lifetime of the testator
ex_1: Nagaadá-áda siá siníng (or ginaadá-áda níya iní nga) bántud sámtang (miéntras) buhì ang íya ginikánan.
ex_1_english: This enclosed field is in his possession or administration during the lifetime of his parent (with the promise of ultimate ownership after the death of his parent).
ex_2: Ginpaadá-adahán níya ang íya mga anák sing mga dútà.
ex_2_english: He distributed some lands among his children.
notes: Especially applied to lands distributed to their children by parents with the stipulation that the parents retain the ownership as long as they live, and may at any time change the previous arrangement

def_1: To cut in thin slices, to slice with a frame-set knife.
ex_1_english: Slice the sweet potato.
ex_2: Iád-ad akó ánay siníng mga patátas.
ex_2_english: Kindly slice these potatoes for me.

def_1: To reject food, slobber, slubber, drivel, slaver, let food slowly flow from the mouth (as babies often do).
ex_1_english: Do not slobber your food.
ex_2: Indì mo pagadadón ang ságing.
ex_2_english: Don’t slobber and spit out, the banana.

def_1: To gossip, divulge or let out secrets, give full rein to the tongue.
ex_1: Indì mo pagad-adón ang mga tinágò sang ímo isigkatáo.
ex_1_english: Don’t let out your neighbour’s secrets.

def_1: A slicer, a frame-set knife for slicing potatoes, radishes, tomatoes and the like

def_2: To be or become sour, sharp, bitter, hot, biting, acid, pungent, acrid.
ex_1: Ang nagakáon sing búnga nga línghod sang kabúgaw maadátan.
ex_1_english: He who eats unripe fruit of a pomelo tree will find it very bitter.
ex_2: Ang sabór siníng kabúgaw nagpaádat sang ákon dílà.
ex_2_english: The taste of this pomelo was like acid on my tongue.
ex_3: Naadátan ang tutúnlan ko.
ex_3_english: I feel a biting in my throat.

def_1: To advise, give warning, instruct, give notice, call attention to.
ex_1_english: Bring it to his notice. Notify him about it. Call his attention to it.
ex_2: Ginadbertí níya akó nga——.
ex_2_english: He sent me word that——. He advised me to——.
compare: tíngga, tíngkaw, paálam, pahibaló, abíso, paabíso

def_1: Progressive, advanced, modern; fast (of a watch).
To promote, ameliorate, introduce progressive methods or modern inventions; to advance, put on.
ex_1_english: Advance me some money.
ex_2: Paadelantahá ang taknáan (relóh) sing napúlò ka minuto.
ex_2_english: Put on the clock ten minutes.
ex_3: Kon magadelantár ikáw sa ákon sing napúlò ka mángmang magakosinéro mo akó.
ex_3_english: If you advance me ten pesos I am willing to become your cook.

def_1: A tree, whose leaves and flowers are supposed to possess cough-curing properties.
Give me. Hand me. Let me have a look.
ex_1_english: Bring it here, I’ll have a look at it.
ex_2: Adí, ákon inâ.
ex_2_english: Hand that to me, it is mine.
ex_3: Adí ang lápis sang ákon útod.
ex_3_english: Give me my brother’s pencil.
notes: adí is probably a contraction of “dálha dirí”—“Bring it here”

def_1: Full of dandruff, scurfy, one affected with dandruff.
A term of endearment used in addressing that class of effeminates known as “agî”: Deary! My dear!

def_2: The ark (of Noe).

def_1: God bless you. God speed you. Good-bye. Farewell.
ex_1: Nagpaadiós siá sa ákon or ginpaadiosán níya akó.
ex_1_english: He bade me good-bye.
ex_2: Ihátag mo iní sa íya nga ipaadiós ko sa íya.
ex_2_english: Give him this from me as a farewell keepsake.
notes: Also used as a verb, mostly with pa—.

def_2: To be or become daylight
def_3: To pass or spend a day.
ex_1_english: The sun is rising.
ex_2: Adlaw na; lakát kitá.
ex_2_english: It’s daylight now; let us go.
ex_3: Kon magádlaw (umádlaw) na, pagadayúnon ta ang áton paglakát.
ex_3_english: When daylight appears, we will continue our march.
ex_4: Sa sulúd sang duhá ukón tátlo ka ádlaw mapamanílà akó.
ex_4_english: Within two or three days I’ll depart for Manila.
ex_5: Naadlawán kitá dídto.
ex_5_english: We passed a full day there.
ex_8: Sang naglígad nga ádlaw nga Miérkoles.

ex_10_english: A day of fasting and abstinence.
ex_11: Sang isá sinâ nga mga ádlaw nga naglilí-gad———.

ex_1_english: It’s full day, rise. It’s bright daylight. Get up.

def_1: To caress, fondle, pet, play with.
To shake, swing, brandish, flourish (a weapon, or the like).
A dish of meat cut up or sliced and mixed with vinegar and various spices

ex_2_english: Buy me some meat, for I am going to prepare from it a dish of adóbo for dinner.
ex_3: Anhon mo iníng kárne?—Adobóhon ko.
ex_3_english: What are you going to do with this meat?—I am going to make adóbo of it.
ex_4: Adobóhi ang mga bisíta.
ex_4_english: Treat the visitors to a dish of adóbo.
ex_5: Makahíbalo ka magadóbo?
ex_5_english: Do you know how to prepare adóbo?
ex_6: Anhon mo iníng  lánggaw?—Iadóbo ko sa kárne.
ex_6_english: What are you using this vinegar for?—I am going to use it for a dish of adóbo.

def_2: To ornament, adorn, embellish, decorate.

ex_1_english: Decorate the church.
ex_2: Iníng púngpung nga búlak iadórno ko sa tulungtúngan sa tungâ sang balatonán.
ex_2_english: With this bunch of flowers I’ll adorn the table in the middle of the reception-room.

def_2: It is there.
ex_1_english: The one that is there.
ex_2: Adto ang ímo kálò.
ex_2_english: There is your hat.
ex_3: Ang ímo kálò ádto dídto.
ex_3_english: Your hat is over there.

def_2: Customs-duty, toll, tax, import duty.

A contr. of tarádyon—irascible, irritable, getting angry on the slightest provocation.
Morning, from near sunrise to mid-day
def_2: To be or become morning.
ex_1_english: This morning.
ex_2: Buás sa ága.
ex_2_english: Tomorrow morning.
ex_3: Kon magága or umága na———.
ex_3_english: When morning comes———.
ex_4: Duhádúha gid kon maagahán pa ang masakít.
ex_4_english: It is very doubtful, whether the sick person (man, woman or child) will live until tomorrow morning.
ex_5: Naagahán kamí sa alipokpokán sang búkid.
ex_5_english: By morning we were on the top of the mountain.
ex_7: Mapaága akó anay kag ugáling malakát.
ex_7_english: I’ll wait till morning and then start.
ex_8: Naagahán silá sang kinánta, sináut, panahî, lagás sa makáwat, etc.
ex_8_english: They sang, danced, sewed, pursued the thief, etc. the whole night through till morning.

def_1: Every morning, regularly in the morning.
ex_1: Agá-ága or sa agá-ága makítà mo siá sa íya sululátan
ex_1_english: Each morning you will find him at his writing desk.

def_1: To serve, especially applied to prospective husbands serving for their betrothed.
ex_1_english: He is serving there for his betrothed.
ex_2: May batásan silá nga ang mga laláki mangágad or magpangágad sa baláy sang íla pangasáw-on (nga íla pangasáw-an).
ex_2_english: They have the custom that the men should serve in the house of their intended wives (of their future parents-in-law).
notes: The Freq. pangágad is mostly used; ágad without the prefix pang occurs in umágad—son-in-law.

def_1: Notwithstanding, in spite of, still, but yet, contrary to what one would expect, in defiance of all one would be led to believe.
ex_1: Nagpaninguhâ siá gid sa pagmánggad, agád namúsmus siá.
ex_1_english: He made great efforts to get rich, and yet he became very poor.
ex_2: Agád ginamligán ko ang ákon pagtikáng sa madánlug nga dálan, tapát gánì nakadúpyas akó.
ex_2_english: Although I carefully picked my steps on the slippery road, yet I slipped.
ex_3: Agád ginahingabút ang Sánta Iglesia sang íya mga kaáway, tapát gánì nagadúgang ang mga tumulóo.
ex_3_english: In spite of the fact that Holy Church is being persecuted by her enemies, her faithful adherents increase.
ex_4: Agád nahúlug akó.
ex_4_english: In spite of all I fell down.
ex_5: Agád napatáy siá!
ex_5_english: Yet he died! Who would have thought that he would die!

def_2: Also: To wait for, expect.
ex_1: Indì ka magdúgay dirâ, kay agád-agádon ko ikáw sing diótay nga oras lámang.
ex_1_english: Don’t tarry there long, for I will wait for you only a short while.

def_1: To separate, cull, pick, weed out.
ex_1: Ag-agá ang mga bató sa balás.
ex_1_english: Pick out the stones from among the sand.
ex_2: Ag-agi ang saburán sang hilamón.
ex_2_english: Weed out the grass from the plot of rice-seedlings.
ex_3: Iág-ag akó ánay sang mga óhot sa humáy.
ex_3_english: Please gather the empty ears from among the rice-grains.
ex_4: Inag-agán mo na sang mga lánsang ang sinapíyo?
ex_4_english: Have you picked out the nails from among the shavings?

def_1: Morning tuba or palm-wine collected from the coconut-palms in the morning.
compare: haponán—tuba gathered in the afternoon or evening

def_1: Morning-, what is done, or takes place, in the morning.
To support, help along invalids or sick persons, etc.
def_2: To help, assist, succour in straits or difficulties.
ex_1_english: Help him along.
ex_2: Ipaágak siá sa ímo sologoón.
ex_2_english: Let your servant lend him support. Order your servant to help him along.
ex_3: Ginaágak silá sang íla mga ábyan.
ex_3_english: They are being helped along in life by their friends.
ex_4: Agákon ko siá sa pagtabók sa subâ.
ex_4_english: I will lead him by the hand whilst crossing the river.

def_1: A squawk, shriek, squeal, an outcry (as of a cock when caught, or the like); to squawk, etc.
To cope with, be able to perform or accomplish, to manage.
ex_1_english: I will readily undertake to perform this work.
ex_2: Makaagám ikáw sinâ?
ex_2_english: Can you cope with that? Can you manage that?

def_2: Also: to take a firm hold of, do (handle, manage) well (carefully).

def_1: To seize, take by force, usurp, snatch away from another.
ex_1: Indì mo pagagáwon ang íya sang ibán.
ex_1_english: Do not take what belongs to another.
ex_2: Ginágaw níla ang íya dútà.
ex_2_english: They took the land away from him by force.
ex_3: Inagáwan akó níla sang ákon bántud nga dídto sa bakólod.
ex_3_english: They seized my plot of enclosed farmland there on the hill.
ex_4: Agáwa sa íya ang binángon.
ex_4_english: Snatch the bolo away from him.
ex_5: Ang mga bátà nagainágaw sang tinápay.
ex_5_english: The children are fighting or scrambling for the bread.
ex_6: Tabúga iníng idô nga malúyag magágaw sang báboy sa bátà.
ex_6_english: Drive off this dog that wants to snatch away the pork from the child.
ex_7_english: Stolen cattle, a kidnapped baby, etc.

def_1: Prepossessing, charming, captivating, attractive and hence having many admirers, clients or customers, being much sought after or resorted to.
ex_1: Agao nga dalága, magtotóon, manugbúlong, buluthóan, etc.
ex_1_english: A charming young lady, a favourite teacher, a doctor much in request, a school or college that attracts many pupils, etc.

def_1: To cope with, manage, be able to perform or accomplish.
ex_1_english: Do your best to cope with it. Try to accomplish it.

def_1: To rise early, be early at work, to do early in the morning, anticipate.
ex_1_english: Be early at the ploughing. Rise early in the morning for the ploughing.
ex_2: Agapá ang pagbúhat sinâ.
ex_2_english: Do it early in the morning.
ex_3: Ginaagapán nila ang pagpangítà sing mga tulún-an, bisán madúgay pa ang pagbukás sang mga buluthúan.
ex_3_english: They are already looking for books, though the opening of the schools is still a long while off.

def_1: Also: Early, premature, too soon, untimely.
ex_1_english: Premature (untimely) death.

def_1: To close, heal, form scabs (said of small-pox, measles and other diseases affecting the skin).
ex_1_english: The small-pox is forming scabs, is slowly healing.
ex_2: Ginaagásan na ang bátà sang típgas (típdas, tígpas), butí, etc.
ex_2_english: The child is now recovering from measles, small-pox, etc.

def_2: To begin healing, start to form scabs, be on the way to recovery.
One who takes (or is accustomed to take) things by force

def_1: What is to be or should be snatched from or saved at once.
ex_1: Sang pagabút námon dídto walâ na siá sing pangalibútan kag agáwagawón gid siá.
ex_1_english: When we arrived there he was already unconscious and it was high time for us to try to save him.

def_1: To trickle, dribble, run down in drops, flow slowly and gently.
ex_1: Nagaágay ang mapaít níya nga lúhà kag nagatúlò sa íya kamót.
ex_1_english: Her bitter tears are trickling down and dropping on her hand.
ex_2: Ináng kalisúd nagpaágay sang íya mga lúhà.
ex_2_english: That trouble brought tears into her eyes.
ex_3: Ang masakit nga bátà ginapaagáyan sing madámù nga mga lúhà sang íya ilóy.
ex_3_english: The sick child is being much wept over by its mother.
ex_4: Nagbúswang na ang íya hubág kag nagágay ang nánà.
ex_4_english: His boil burst and the pus flowed out.
ex_5: Nagpangabúdlay siá sing támà sa ínit nga ang masulúg nga bálhas nagágay sa tanán nga mga buhôbúhò sang íya pánit.
ex_5_english: He worked very hard in the heat of the sun, so that streams of perspiration poured from all the pores of his skin.

def_1: Decomposition, rottenness, decay, blight, produced by the action of small worms, vermin, insects, parasites (both vegetable and animal), the decayed parts frequently being turned into powder.
def_2: Also used as a verb.
ex_1: May agáy-ay or ginaagáy-ay ang káhoy, bugás, tápì, salúg, etc.
ex_1_english: The wood—, rice—, board—, floor—, is worm-eaten.
ex_2: Igátong na lang ang inagáy-ay nga káhoy.
ex_2_english: Use the worm- eaten timber for firewood.
ex_3: Ang kadiós inagay-ayán na man.
ex_3_english: The black peas have also become infested with blight.

def_1: Dumb, mum, silent, taciturn (applied to persons who habitually talk little, and rarely allow themselves to be drawn into a conversation, but particularly said of those, who on being questioned or asked an explanation keep a sullen or stubborn silence).
ex_1_english: A very taciturn man.
ex_2: Iníng batà ágbà gid.
ex_2_english: This is a very stubborn child from whom it is difficult to get an answer to questions.
ex_3: Kaágbà sa ímo.
ex_3_english: How stubborn you are! Have you lost your tongue!
ex_4: Indì ka maginágbà or magpakaágbà.
ex_4_english: Don’t pretend to be deaf and dumb. Don’t act as if you could not speak.
notes: ágbà is related to apâ, but in speaking of persons afflicted with dumbness “apâ” only is used and never “ágbà”

def_2: Something that inspires fear or creates a panic; fearful, terrific.

def_1: To put one’s arms on or round another’s shoulder.
ex_1_english: They are walking with their arms round each other’s shoulders.
ex_2: Agbayí siá.
ex_2_english: Place your arm on his shoulder.
ex_3: Indì ka magágbay sa íya.
ex_3_english: Don’t put your arm on his or her shoulder.
ex_4: Paagbayón mo ang masakít.
ex_4_english: Let the sick person put his arm on your shoulder.
ex_5: Sa dakû nga kakáhas nagágbay siá sa kay Fulána, apang dáyon siá níya sinúmbag kag siníkway.
ex_5_english: With great boldness he put his arm on Miss N.N.’s shoulder, but immediately he received a slap from her and was repulsed with contempt.

def_2: To be converted into ashes.
ex_1_english: My cigar is converted into ashes.
ex_2: Pilá ka abáno ang ginaágbon mo sa isá ka ádlaw?
ex_2_english: How many cigars do you convert into ashes in the course of one day?

def_1: A kind of tree with leaves spotted with green and white.
To invite, to ask or request one’s presence.
ex_1_english: Invite him.
ex_2: Ginágda mo na ang tanán mo nga mga ábyan?
ex_2_english: Have you invited all your friends?
ex_3: Ang áton piésta pagaagdahán ko sing madámù nga mga Párì.
ex_3_english: I shall invite many priests to assist at our feast. I shall request the presence of many priests at our feast.
ex_4: Ari na ang mga inágda.
ex_4_english: The invited guests are now here.
ex_5: Nalipatán níya sa pagágda sánday Pedro. Paagdahón ko siá sa íla or ipaágda ko silá sa íya.
ex_5_english: He forgot to invite Peter and his friends or Peter and his family. I’ll make him invite them.
ex_6: Padálhan ko siá kuntánì sing sulát nga iágda ko sa íya, ápang walâ gánì akó kasáyod kon diín siá nagapuyô karón.
ex_6_english: I should like to send him a letter of invitation, but I do not know where he is staying at present.

def_1: Useful, serviceable, of use, worth something, capable, reliable.

def_2: To do slowly,—leisurely,—lazily, to be slow at work, dilatory in execution, dull of understanding.
ex_1_english: Why do you work so slowly?
ex_2: Indì ka magágday sa pagóbra or indì mo pagagdayón ang pagóbra.
ex_2_english: Don’t be lazy at work.
compare: hínay, lágway, lágday, lamínday, luyò, búndol, pákok

def_2: Dull, stupid, slow of understanding.
ex_1: Agdayán siá sa pagtoón sa paghámbal sing ininglís.
ex_1_english: He is slow in learning to speak English.

def_1: A kind of shrub with rather dark leaves.
def_2: Hence: to darken, be or become dark.
ex_1: Nagágdom ang íya guyá, kay nagasúngon.
ex_1_english: His face is darkening, for he is angry.
ex_2: Nagpaágdom siá sang íya guyá.
ex_2_english: He darkened his face to the colour of ágdom. He glowered.

def_1: A small tree much used for fences.
Soft, effeminate, not manly, said of men with feminine voice and manners, hermaphrodite.

def_2: To go by, pass by, pass through.
ex_1: Ang mga ági kag bilín sang salâ.
ex_1_english: The traces and remains of sin.
ex_2: Ang mga ági sang íya kabúhì.
ex_2_english: The incidents of his life.
ex_3: Kon magági ka dirí, hapíti kamí.
ex_3_english: If you pass this way, visit us.
ex_4: Indì ka makaági dirâ, kay nakodalán ang umá.
ex_4_english: You cannot pass through there, for the field is fenced in.
ex_5: Ang dálan nga íla ginágyan (ginagíhan)—.
ex_5_english: The road over which they passed—.
ex_6: Iági akó siníng tulún- an sa kay Fuláno.
ex_6_english: Kindly hand this book over to N.N. in passing.
ex_7_english: Tomorrow I’ll call for you in passing (and take you along).
ex_8_english: Tomorrow I’ll visit you on my way.
ex_9: Paágyon mo kamí sa ímo umá.
ex_9_english: Let us pass through your field.
ex_10: Dílì mo pagpaágyan sa íla ang áton umá.
ex_10_english: Don’t allow them to pass through our field.
ex_11_english: I have never been there yet, I have had no occasion to pass that way, I have not seen or passed that place at all.

def_1: Passing, transitory, transient, going by or through occasionally
def_2: To pass by occasionally, to visit now and then.
A little effeminate, womanish.
To resemble, to be like or similar.
ex_1_english: They resemble each other in their ways or behaviour.
ex_2: Agid-agída silá, kon nagaparého ang íla dágway.
ex_2_english: Compare them to see, whether their shape is the same.
ex_3: Iníng baláy, agíd- ágid sa ámon.
ex_3_english: This house is something like ours.

def_1: The temple, the part of the head between the ear and forehead.
Stunted in growth, undersized, lean and weak
def_2: To become stunted, etc.
ex_1_english: An undersized person.
ex_2: Nagagíl-agíl siá sa balatían.
ex_2_english: He became stunted through illness.

def_1: Stunted, kept back or checked in growth, underdeveloped.

def_2: Mísas de Aguináldo—Solemn Votive-Masses celebrated early in the morning from the 16th to the 24th of December.

def_1: A firebrand, a partly burning or smouldering piece of wood.
A kind of tall grass with sharp-edged blades.
The mange, scab or itch of dogs and other domestic animals.

def_2: Pertaining to the mange called agís-is.

def_1: To follow one after another, to succeed regularly.
ex_1: Agisóda (-óra) or iagísod ang ímo mga buluhatón.
ex_1_english: Perform your tasks one after another. Do your various duties in regular order.
ex_2: Paagisóda (-óra) ang mga bátà.
ex_2_english: Make the children follow in line, one behind the other.
notes: The plural form alagísod is more in use

def_1: A harsh sound of creaking or grating
def_2: To creak, to grate.
ex_1_english: Sand grates on the teeth.
ex_2: Ang balás nagapaáglot sang ngípon.
ex_2_english: Sand makes the teeth grate.

def_1: A kind of vine and its stem used for binding purposes and wickerwork.
Shunning work, avoiding labour, lazy, slothful
def_2: To be or become lazy, slothful, indolent, averse to work.
def_3: Mostly used with pa- in the meaning of: to shirk or avoid work, to perform lazily.
ex_1: Indì ka magpaagohós sang pangabúdlay or indì mo pagpaagohosán ang pagpangabúdlay.
ex_1_english: Don’t be lazy or indolent at your work. Don’t work lazily.
ex_2: Ang mga matámad nagapaagohós sang pangabúdlay.
ex_2_english: Lazy people are averse to hard work.

def_1: A plant, whose tender shoots are edible.

def_2: To be lazy, indolent, slothful.
ex_1_english: Don’t be lazy.
ex_2: Indì mo pagagólan ang pagtúman sang ímo mga katungdánan.
ex_2_english: Don’t be indolent in the performance of your duties.

def_2: A little lazy, somewhat indolent.
ex_1_english: A rather lazy fellow.
ex_2: Iníng kaláyo agól-agól láng.
ex_2_english: This fire burns dull,—does not burn bright.

def_1: A trickster, sneak, cheat, thief in a small way
def_2: To trick, cheat, deceive, obtain under some plausible pretext.
ex_1_english: He deprived me of my umbrella by a mean trick.
ex_2: Agongá ang íya kálò or agongi siá sang íya kálò.
ex_2_english: Get hold of his hat by some stratagem.
ex_3: Likawí ang mga agóng kag makáwat.
ex_3_english: Avoid sneaks and thieves.
compare: dáyà, límbong, tíkas, takáb, káwtì, lág-it

def_2: Knell, death-bell, passing-bell
ex_1_english: Whom is the passing- bell ringing for?
ex_2: Paagoniási siá.
ex_2_english: Have the passing-bell rung for him.

def_1: To agonize, struggle between life and death, to be in the death-agony.
ex_1: Ang nabadlisán kag nabiatikohán kaína nagaagonisár na, konó.
ex_1_english: They say, that the one who received Extreme Unction and Viaticum a short while ago is now in his agony.

def_1: Mouldiness, mustiness, mould. Also used as a verb.
ex_1: Iníng tinápay may agóp-op or ginaagóp-op.
ex_1_english: This bread is mouldy.
ex_2: Indì akó kaúyon sang tinápay nga inagóp-op or inagop-opán.
ex_2_english: I do not like to eat musty or mouldy bread.
ex_3: Indì mo pagpaagóp-opón ang tinápay, kán-on, dólse, etc.
ex_3_english: Do not let the bread, rice, sweetmeats, etc. become mildewed or musty.

def_1: A kind of snail similar to tamburukò and tibótíbo.
An exclamation of pain and suffering.
ex_1_english: Oh, dear me. Oh, the pain of this boil of mine!
ex_2: Agóy, daw sa dílì na akó makabatás siníng kahápdì.
ex_2_english: Oh, dear, I can hardly stand this pain any longer.

def_1: A small crab living in holes in the sand on the beach.
A hank of yarn or thread. Also used as a verb.
ex_1: Agpangá ang binúlung nga búlak sang búlak.
ex_1_english: Make up the spun cotton into hanks.
ex_2: Bunáng nga inágpang.
ex_2_english: Yarn in hanks, yarn by the hank.

def_2: Rural inspector or overseer

notes: Even in Hiligáynon ágrot seems to be more commonly used than áglot

def_2: Boasting, bragging, exaggerating talk.
ex_1: Agrót gid siá; lakás na man ang agrót nga íya sinúgid.
ex_1_english: He is a great braggart; his exaggerations are really too much.
ex_2: Indì ka magsúgid sang ímo agrót.
ex_2_english: Don’t boast. Don’t tire other people with your boastful talk.

def_1: To work another’s fields for part of the produce.
ex_1_english: I work this farm only as a tenant.
ex_2: Sín-o ang ginaagsahán mo?
ex_2_english: Who is the owner of your leasehold?
ex_3: Ang agsadór ko amó ang nagaágsa sang ákon dútà.
ex_3_english: My tenant is the one who works my farm.
ex_4: Ginapaágsa níya ang íya dútà sa isá ka salalígan nga agsadór.
ex_4_english: He let his land on lease to a trustworthy tenant.
ex_5: Kon may lúyag ka ipaágsa ko sa ímo ang ákon umá.
ex_5_english: If you like, I’ll let you have my farm in tenure by lease.
ex_6_english: Become his tenant. Take his land in tenure by lease. Take some of his land on lease.

def_1: The one to whom a field is let or leased for part of the produce, a lessee, tenant, leaseholder.
To chip—, trim—, dress—, hew—, wood by cutting or splitting off small pieces.
ex_1_english: Dress the wood by chipping.
ex_2: Inágsap nga káhoy.
ex_2_english: A chip—, splinter—, of wood.
ex_3: Ang mga inágsap sang kawáyan ginapaámak sa kaláyo.
ex_3_english: Bamboo-trimmings are useful for lightning or kindling a fire.
ex_4: Iágsap akó ánay siníng káhoy.
ex_4_english: Please trim this piece of wood for me.
ex_5: Nagtínlò na ang inagsapán nga halígi.
ex_5_english: The post that was trimmed has become smooth.
ex_6_english: Let the carpenter trim this post.

def_1: To fly off, scatter, spray, splash, bespatter.
ex_1: Sang pagbí-al ko sang káhoy ang mga inágsap nagágsik sa malayô.
ex_1_english: When I split the wood, the chips flew to a distance.
ex_2: Naagsikán akó sang lúnang.
ex_2_english: I got bespattered with mud.
ex_3: Indì ka magpalapít dirâ, kay básì maagsikán ka sing binílbig nga bató.
ex_3_english: Don’t go near there, for you may be hit by a flying piece of stone.
ex_4: Paagsiká ang bató.
ex_4_english: Let the stone-chips fly.

ex_1_english: Oh, the child is as black as a negro.
ex_2: Diín ka man magágtà?
ex_2_english: Where did you become so black?
ex_3: Naagtaán gid akó siníng áti.
ex_3_english: I consider this Negrito very black.

def_2: To go to, etc.

def_1: Tidal wave, the wake of a ship
def_2: Sea current, stream
ex_1: Nagaaguáhi pa ang húblag ni Fuláno.
ex_1_english: N.N.’s movement (agitation, scheme, policy) is still gathering force.

def_1: A common shrub, whose leaves are made use of to keep off or drive away bugs.
To support, guide, help along persons who cannot walk well by themselves
def_2: To assist people in their necessities.
ex_1_english: Help along this lame person.
ex_2: Iagubáy akó ánay siníng masakít nga batà.
ex_2_english: Please support this sick child for me.
ex_3: Ipaagubáy ko lang iníng makaloló-oy nga tigúlang sa mga mádre.
ex_3_english: I’ll get the nuns to take care of this poor old man.
ex_4: Makaagubáy ka sa íya?
ex_4_english: Can you help him along?
ex_5: Ginagubáy námon siá, kay malúya siá maglakát.
ex_5_english: We helped him along, as he had little strength to walk.

def_1: That, in order that, so that
def_2: Agúd índì or agúd dílì—lest, in order that not
ex_1_english: Study, that you may become learned.
ex_2: Basáha ang tulún-an sing matalupángdon, agúd ímo masáyran ang ginabása mo.
ex_2_english: Read the book with attention, in order that you may understand what you read.
ex_3: Kápti ang alobáybay, agúd índì ka mahúlog.
ex_3_english: Keep hold of the handrail, lest you should fall down.
ex_4: Amligí ang pagdalá mo siníng báso, agúd dílì mabúong.
ex_4_english: Carry this glass with care, in order that it may not break.
notes: The particle “nga” is frequently added to agúd (agúd nga, agúd nga dílì, etc.), but it may be left out without change of meaning.

ex_1_english: He is quite useless.
ex_2: Ang ákon plúma walâ na sing águd.
ex_2_english: My pen is of no use any more.

ex_1: Diótay lang ang agúd-agúd siníng táo.
ex_1_english: This man is not of much use.

def_1: To obtain, reach, enjoy the possession of, gain, get, acquire, reap.
ex_1: Ang mga matárung magaágum or magahiágum kunína sang himáyà sa lángit.
ex_1_english: The just will finally enjoy the glory of heaven.
ex_2: Pagaagúman ko gid ang búnga sang ákon ginkabudlayán.
ex_2_english: I shall surely reap the fruit of my labours.
ex_3: Ipaágum mo sa íya ang ígò nga bálus.
ex_3_english: Grant him a fitting reward.
ex_4: Paagúma siá sang ímo kamót.
ex_4_english: Let him feel your hand i.e. strike, box, slap, hit him.
ex_5: Inagúman na níya ang íya nga ginhándum sang madámù nga mga túig.
ex_5_english: He has now reached the goal desired for many years.

def_1: A kind of fish that is frequently cut in two, salted and dried in the sun.
ex_1_english: Salt agumá-a.

def_2: To coo

def_1: To wheeze, be short of breath.
ex_1_english: Kon mamuérsa ka sa paghákwat siníng bató, magaagúnta ka.
ex_2: If you exert yourself much in lifting this stone, you will gasp for breath.

def_1: A term of endearment used towards persons that are older than the one who addresses them.
To clean or scrape with a sharp-edged tool.
ex_1_english: Clean the rattan. Scrape the rattan smooth and clean.
ex_2: Owáy nga inagúsan.
ex_2_english: Clean, trimmed or dressed rattan ready for binding or weaving purposes.
ex_3: Iágus ang binángon sa siní nga liníyas nga kawáyan.
ex_3_english: Scrape this piece of split bamboo clean with the bolo.

def_2: To have—, entertain—, harbour—, a grudge, etc.
ex_1: May agutílò or nagaagutílò siá sa ákon.
ex_1_english: He has a grudge against me.

def_1: Decay, rottenness, decomposition, caries of the teeth.
ex_1_english: The kalawág-plant is a remedy for decaying teeth.

def_1: Pertaining to, or suffering from, decaying teeth.
ex_1: Ang agutingón índì magkáon sing dólse, kay magabúsug ang íya ngipon.
ex_1_english: One suffering from decayed teeth should not eat sweets, for it will give him tooth-ache.

def_2: To moan, groan, sigh.
ex_1: Nagadígwà siá, nagaaguyóng kag nagahápò ang íya ginháwa.
ex_1_english: He is retching (as if about to vomit), groaning and breathing with difficulty.

def_2: Perfume, scented water, scent.
ex_1: Ano nga ágwa ang ímo ginagámit?
ex_1_english: What sort of scent do you use?
notes: Water for drinking, cooking and washing is nearly always called “túbig” or “túbì”, whilst the term “ágwa” is almost exclusively applied to perfumes

def_1: To get or fetch water (especially with two tins suspended from a pole carried over the shoulder)
ex_1: Agwáda ka or magagwáda ka sing túbig sa subâ kag dálha dirí.
ex_1_english: Fetch water from the river and bring it here.
ex_2: Agwadáhi akó sing túbig sa madalî, kay ilútò ko sa panyága.
ex_2_english: Fetch me some water at once, for I’m going to use it for cooking the dinner.

def_1: Vessel for fetching or carrying water, water-bucket.

ex_1: Húy, agwadór, agwadáhi akó sing túbig sa ímo agwadahán.
ex_1_english: Hello! Water-carrier fetch me some water in your bucket.

def_1: To bear, tolerate, suffer, let pass, put up with.
ex_1: Dáw dílì na akó makaagwánta sinâ.
ex_1_english: I seem not to be able to bear it any longer.
ex_2: Anhon mo, kóndì magagwánta lang?
ex_2_english: What can you do, but suffer it patiently?
ex_3: Agwantahá lang!
ex_3_english: Just bear it with resignation!

def_1: Robust, strong with great powers of resistance to fatigue, pain and stress
def_2: One who can stand or bear much, one suffering patiently or with fortitude.
ex_1: Agwantádo siá sa tungâ sang tanán nga pagpangabúdlay kag kalisdánan.
ex_1_english: He bears up bravely in the midst of all fatigues and difficulties.
ex_2: Dúro siá kaagwantádo.
ex_2_english: He can stand very much. He is able to bear—, support—, a good deal.

def_2: Alcohol
To be lively or of a cheerful disposition
def_4: To exude, to break forth, particularly applied to matter or pus oozing out of a wound, ulcer or boil.
ex_1: Ang komód nga táo dílì agwása.
ex_1_english: A man inclined to retirement and silence is not of a lively disposition.
ex_2: Nagaagwása na ang hubág.
ex_2_english: Pus is now flowing from the tumour.
ex_3: Ginapaagwása níla ang hubág.
ex_3_english: They are using remedies to cause the pus to flow from the tumour.
ex_4: Paagwasáha ang hubág.
ex_4_english: Make the tumour (by pressure, etc.) discharge its matter.
ex_5: Ipaagwása akó ánay sang ákon hubág sa lí-og.
ex_5_english: Kindly remove the matter (by pressure, poultices, etc.) from the tumour on my neck.
ex_6: Si Fuláno dúro gid kaagwása sa íya mga sugilánon.
ex_6_english: N.N. is very cheerful in his talk. N.N. is a chatterbox.

def_1: A very poisonous snake, growing to the thickness of a man’s arm, living mostly in the jungle and looking for its prey, wild chickens, etc., at night-time.
notes: It is quite dangerous to meet an agwáson, for instead of gliding away it often attacks persons coming upon it.

def_1: To beseech, ask fervently, insist on obtaining some favour, importune.
ex_1: Nagahâ siá sa ákon sing bulúng sa pilás.
ex_1_english: He asked me insistently for some medicine for the wound.
ex_2: Ginahaán akó níya sing diótay nga humáy, kay nawád-an siá.
ex_2_english: He earnestly begged a little rice of me, for he had run short of it.
ex_3: Dilì matúod nga akó amó ang nagahâ sa íla, kóndì, hinonóo gánì, silá nagpangáyò sa ákon.
ex_3_english: It is not true that I importuned them, but, on the contrary, they asked me.

def_2: To be or become daring, bold, impertinent.
ex_1: Nagaháng siá galî or ginahangán níya galî!
ex_1_english: Was he really so bold!
ex_2: Magaháng ka lang sa pagkúhà sing lubí or ahangí lang ang pagkúhà sing lubí.
ex_2_english: Pluck up courage and take a coconut.

ex_1: Karón may áhao na nga ginatíg-ang.
ex_1_english: There is new rice now being cooked or there is now new rice to cook.
ex_2: Ang áhao dílì maúkad.
ex_2_english: New rice does not swell much (when boiled).

ex_1: Ahasí (pangahasí) lang ang pagbukás sang ganháan.
ex_1_english: Open the door boldly.

def_1: To do something prematurely, before the regular or proper time or even against one’s inclination.
ex_1: Ahatá lang ang pagpópò sang páhò.
ex_1_english: Pluck the mango, even though it is not yet quite ripe.
ex_2: Ginaahát níla ang ságing nga línghod.
ex_2_english: They are eating unripe bananas.
ex_3: Ahatón mo ang buót mo sa paglakát, bisan índì ka malúyag.
ex_3_english: Make up your mind to go, although you do not like to.
ex_4: Masakít karón ang íya solóksolók, kay man ginahát níya ang mga sirig-wélas nga hiláw.
ex_4_english: Of course he has stomach-ache, he has eaten green plums.

def_1: Compelled, constrained, forced, obliged, against one’s will, nolens volens
def_2: Sudden, premature.
All, complete, entire, without exception.
compare: lúnlun, lubús, túnay, lúnsay, pulús, pasáy

ex_1_english: A crumpled jacket.
Alas, bad luck!
ex_2: Aháy, pagkalisúd sang ákon maláut nga kapaláran nga dáw waláy paaliwánsan!
ex_2_english: Oh, the wretchedness of my fate from which there is no escape!

ex_1_english: They are playing chess.

def_2: Pawnbroker’s shop, an agent’s or commissioner’s bureau, especially one for the advancing of money on pledges or for buying second-hand goods.

def_1: To treat with neglect, to disregard, pay no attention to, to ignore, take no heed or account of, to put aside contemptuously.
ex_1_english: They are neglecting their stepchildren.
ex_2: Ahíg-ahigá lang inâ.
ex_2_english: Simply ignore it or treat it with contempt or pass it over without notice.

def_2: Leek

def_1: A kind of odoriferous flowering plant.
To wash, rinse, pour water over something or somebody, and the like.
ex_1_english: Pour water over me.
ex_2: Iáhog ang túbig sa úlo ko.
ex_2_english: Pour the water over my head.
ex_3: Ahóga ang ákon likód sang túbig.
ex_3_english: Pour water over my back.
ex_4: May inugáhog ikáw?
ex_4_english: Have you a scoop or vessel for pouring out liquids?
ex_5: Sang íla pagpalígos sa subâ nagahogáy or nagahogánay silá.
ex_5_english: When they took a bath in the river they poured water over each other.

def_2: Leek
ex_1: Butangí sing áhos or ahósi ang kárne.
ex_1_english: Put some garlic with the meat.

def_1: To tease, to stroke or caress a child against its will, to pat or fondle a child averse to such handling till it cries, gets angry or runs away.
ex_1_english: Tease him.
ex_2: Ipaahós mo sa íya ang bátà.
ex_2_english: Let him tease the baby.
ex_3: Nagmasakít ang bátà kay inahós ni Fulána nga áswang.
ex_3_english: The baby got sick, because the witch N.N. had caressed it or had teased it.

def_1: An exclamation to draw another’s attention: Hey! Hello! Ahoy!
ex_1_english: Hey, kindly wait for me.
ex_2: Ahóy! kamó dirâ! Kumarí kamó dirí kag bulígan nínyo kamí.
ex_2_english: Hello, you there! Come here and help us!

def_2: Liveliness, cheerfulness, sprightliness
def_3: Gracefulness, elegance in manner, bearing, carriage, etc.

def_1: To sell well, be much in demand, be much sought after.
ex_1: Nagáka karón sa Ilongílong ang páhò, ságing, ísdà kag manók.
ex_1_english: At present mangoes, bananas, fish and chickens are much in demand in Iloilo.
ex_2: Sang túig nga tinalíkdan maíwat ang pamaligyáon sang sibúkaw, ápang nián nagáka na.
ex_2_english: Last year the market for sibúkaw-wood was dull, stagnant, but now it is much in demand.
compare: maáka, kaáka, mabákal, bákal, ágaw, dásà

def_1: To tear off, to bark, to strip (a tree of its bark).
ex_1_english: Strip the bark off the tree.
ex_2: Ak-akí ang káhoy sang íya pánit.
ex_2_english: Strip the tree of its bark.
ex_3: Pánit nga inák-ak.
ex_3_english: Bark torn or pulled off.
ex_4: Káhoy ngga inak-akán.
ex_4_english: A tree stript of its bark.

def_2: To throb.
ex_1: Nagabukál na ang túbig, kay nagaakál-akál na.
ex_1_english: The water is boiling now, for it is bubbling.
ex_2: Nagaakál-akál ang tutúnlan ko.
ex_2_english: My throat throbs.
ex_3: Indì mo pagbak-itón ang tsaréra, kóndì paakál-akalá ánay ang túbig sing maáyo.
ex_3_english: Don’t take the tea-kettle off the fire, but let the water first boil properly.

def_2: By chance, perchance, perhaps, maybe, mayhap, possibly.
A term of endearment used towards small girls, sweethearts, daughters, daughters-in-law and other near female relations.
ex_1_english: Where is darling?

Anger, ire, wrath, rage, passion, choler, fury, indignation
